Patricia. What --has happened? But Patricia dances past him, dragging in her duffle and singing as she goes. It’s odd behavior. They are going to try to keep her alive after all. He glances up at her. He flips back through the notes. Th name “Markos” has come up before, several times. Klempere has called it a “besessenheit.” An obsession.

Don’t say that name--! But then she tries to make herself laugh, as if she’s hav a very good time.  PATRICIA (CONT’D) I’m not supposed to be here! It’s the middle of the day! You’re a nice boy. She realizes she’s said too many real things in a row and sembles. She’s terrified. PATRICIA (CONT’D) I’m having so much fun I don’t know why you never brought me here be- fore! A long beat. You think they can hear you now. She shoots him a look. Then a frightened nod. She dances window and begins singing Bowie’s “Heroes,” again as if s at some kind of club. She has her eyes closed now, really trying to put herself another place and time.

They took my hair. My urine. They took my eyes. There’s more to that building than what you see. CLOSE ON: In her file, he writes: << Her delusion has dee ened into panic. She feels her constructed mythology is c firmed. >>

Patricia--

But I was told--
Dear. You have no formal training or references. Madame Blanc took your insistance to come encourag- ingly. That’s why you’re here at all. Tanner is not being cruel, just clear. A beat. Susie nods

You can keep time in your head. Susie puts the cassette on the floor, out of the way, tak center floor, and begins. The first movement of her audit is so razor sharp and cutting it is startling. INT. There are photos of the company’s history ba to the 1910s on the walls, and some personal effects of T ner’s on her desk, including a lovely dried lotus pod tha been painted red. They did it while we were in mor- ning rehearsal. Put her things in shipping boxes.
Do you think she had to go under- ground or something? With what's go- ing on?

(irritated) We don't know what happened! Susie glances into the hall and briefly meets eyes with o of the passing girls, SARA (20s), aka Voice #3.  13. But Miss Tanner comes in with MISS VENDEGAST (60s) and cl the door. Miss Vendegast is smiling.

I’ve just spoken with Madame Blanc. Well done, Miss Bannion. Susie can’t stifle the smile spreading across her face. S can barely keep her seat, she is so excited. MISS TANNER (CONT’D) I imagine you’ll need to return home to settle things and make ar- rangements for moving to Berlin--
No, no. I-- I’m ready now. I can start now. A beat. Tanner nods.

(re: Vendegast) Fine, then. This is Miss Vendegast. She acts as housemother to company members who reside here, which is the majority. We operate as a sort of collective. (pointedly) As we cannot pay our dancers much by way of a salary, we are ina position to offer dormitory-style rooms rent-free, which is one way we've found to sew up the differ- ence.
You don’t charge anything --at all?
Not a mark. Susie is so relieved, she can’t keep the tears out of her eyes for a moment. Miss Tanner softens.
I’m sorry to cry!
In this company, we understand fully the importance of a woman's financial autonomy. (beat) (MORE )
Normally, we'd be full up at this time of year, but we’ve had a room open.
Patricia's. She says this matter-of-factly. Miss Vendegast looks at M Tanner. Tanner squints at Susie, slightly alarmed.
Some girls were talking about her in the hall just now.

Ah. Now that you’re one of us, I won't be coy. Patricia has left the company under sad circumstances. We think she won’t be back. (beat) So there's room, if you’d like. We can even move you in this afternoon so you don’t have to pay another night at your hotel.
We'll send one of the girls to help you with your luggage after lunch. Is that all right.
Yes. Thank you. --It’s perfect.

Three stories below, Susie walks back across the entrance hall on her way out, trying to contain her excitement and lief. INT. HOTEL PFAU, SUSIE’S ROOM -- NIGHT A storm is coming down hard and with THUNDER. Susie is in hotel window looking down to the street. A taxi pulls up. Sara, the dancer from the corridor, gets out.

Sara looks up at the hotel and sees Susie. She waves. Sus waves back, already running to get out of the downpour. INT. HOTEL PFAU, SUSIE’S ROOM -- NIGHT Sara comes in soaked. She’s clearly from money. She doesn overtly advertise this. Her clothes are lovely, but it’s in the way she carries herself.

I'm sorry I’m late. It’s the rain. Whenever it rains, everyone in Ber- lin jumps in a cab. And like an mo- ron, I just let ours go. It’1l take an hour to get another one now. Oh I’m Sara. We’ll have to take our chances in the street. You have an umbrella? Susie shakes her head. SARA (CONT’D) (looking around) That’s okay. We can borrow one from the hotel if they have them. But Susie’s luggage is still open on the floor, things ev where.
When you weren't here by six I had to take the room for another night.
I’m so sorry! Everything was a mess at the Company today. (off Susie’s look) Why are you smiling?
Berlin. You said “everybody in Ber- lin” a second ago and I thought: That includes me now. I live here now. Sara smiles at Susie’s guilelessness.  16.
Yes. Congrats. I heard you here a sensation today. Susie shrugs, happy. There’s a roll of THUNDER. SARA (CONT’D) I should maybe go before this gets worse, then. I’1l come back in the morning?
If it will be so bad getting a cab, sleep here if you want. We can push the beds apart. I have an extra nightgown-- Sara considers the invitation, surprised and moved by Sus openness.
We’ll miss dinner, but we can order room service. To celebrate! (intuiting) On me! As a “welcome to Berlin.”

They finish plates of meatballs and Jagerschnitzel. They ordered big German beers, which they’ve drunk. The storm side has gotten worse. The power goes out for a moment, t comes back on. SARA (CONT’D) Have you called your family yet, to tell them? Sara is a little drunk. The nightgowns are almost comical conservative. Sara looks at the stitching and sees: it’s sewn. SARA (CONT’D) Did you tell me where you’re from?

Tell me about Madame Blanc! She came into my audition, but she left right after. The lights go out and this time they don’t come back on. Lightning occasionally brightens the windows, giving them light.  17.

She's incredible. The way she trans- mits her work, her energy. When it shines on you, it’s --addictive, is the word for it. And she’s tough-- She kept the company alive through the war--think about that--when the Reich just wanted women to shut off their minds and keep their uteruses open, there was Blanc. (beat) --La vraie chose!

Is that French? I don’t even know! There is a SUDDEN DETONATION outside nearby, markedly dif ent from thunder. It shakes the glass. They run and open window to look. It came from down the street. They can’t from this angle, so Sara leans out, into the rain.
I can smell it. A bomb.
A bomb?! Susie keeps her from falling out. Police SIRENS are comin

There’s a bank that way. She comes back into the room, looking at Susie. SARA (CONT’D) Don’t you know what’s happening here? The hijackers are negotiating a release for the Stammheim prison- ers tonight. There are riots. Susie doesn’t answer. SARA (CONT’D) The RAF? Baader-Meinhof?
I don’t know what that is.
They kidnapped an executive. During the war he was Nazi SS. An officer. Now he runs the German Employer's Association-- (beat) (MORE )

You don’t get how awful that is, do you? Susie shakes her head: This means nothing to her. Sara sh vers and closes the window. SARA (CONT’D) I didn’t either. Until I came here. --And my Father’s in the Diplomatic Service. Susie goes to the bathroom and comes back with a thick to She sees Sara is now sitting on the bed in tears.
What is it?! Susie sits on the bed next to her.
I’m sorry. All of this-- I’m just worried about a friend. It’s been an terrible day.
I heard you talking about her in the hall. I knew something was wrong.
She just left this morning, telling Ms. Tanner she had a “family emer- gency.” No one knows what to do.
What do you mean?
She was active, in some political groups. So we don’t know where she is, really. If she’s in hiding, if she’s all right. (beat) I just want to know she’s if all right.
Is she a very good dancer? Sara looks at Susie, at her earnestness and innocence. It shouldn’t, but it comforts her.  19.
Yes. Very good. But an even better friend.
Then I bet you’ll hear from her tom- morrow. --Right? Sara finally nods, then smiles, grateful for the comfort.

An early morning sun is drying the pavements from last night’s storm. It’s shaken leaves out of the trees and pl ered them onto the curbs and sidewalks. Klemperer makes his way slowly up a main avenue in his ne borhood. It is a squatter’s part of town, full of art pio ers and youth in revolt. The ones who recognize him nod t him like a grandpa. He buys a morning newspaper beside a way station. Headlines announce the Palestinian hijackers Flight 181 have flown the captured Lufthansa to Bahrain.

Klemperer rides the train into East Germany. Next to him middle-aged PRIEST. His lip is cut and swollen. The other a WOMAN (20) with bitten nails and a hospital band around wrist. In her lap is a sleeping BOY (3). When the train stops at FriedrichstraBe Station, everyone made to get out.  20.
Klemperer is in line to show his papers at the police che He is waved through and heads up the stairs into the Russ Sector. One of the armed guards also gives Klemperer a no as to a familiar face.

Klemperer continues down the avenue two blocks. East Berl is visibly still on its knees from the war, even years la The rubble and the decay, has the feeling of having been ied, but not yet confronted. He turns off and walks toward a small cobbled corner of a otherwise nondescript intersection. There is a small foun in the stonework, but nothing comes out of it. There is a sonry bench there just wide enough room for two people to at the lip of its dry bowl. Klemperer takes a seat there. We are witnessing a habit, a ritual, possibly a daily occ rence. He says out loud, to no one, like a mantra:
<< And maybe today, my love. >> Then he opens his paper and begins eating his breakfast o of a waxed paper bag he’s brought with him.

<< They're out again today, Doctor. For the prisoners. Do you think it will end today? >> INT. KLEMPERER’S APARTMENT, SITTING ROOM -- DAY Klemperer is not listening. He is looking at the bags Pat cia left behind. They’ve been moved to the corner.  21. He goes to them. He unzips the duffle and begins looking through it. Clothes. Boots. Then a notebook. He hesitates and then opens it. It is near full with entries, drawings hand-drawn maps. He begins reading.
Susie and Sara carry Susie’s luggage up to the third floo passing the mirrors Susie saw the day before. She’s now r flected in them from just below.

They come into a corridor of dormitory-type rooms. Some o the girls are stealing a few moments in their rooms betwe breakfast and rehearsal. When Susie appears on the floor, few come out and introduce themselves. Susie smiles at them, greets them. Why don’t you try speaking to me like you love me for a change-- Sara rolls her eyes and brings Susie to the end of one co ridor, pointing out as they pass a room at the end:
That’s my room-- The hall turns right, then right again revealing a parall corridor, also with dorm rooms. Susie’s is first. They go SARA (CONT’D) We're sort of neighbors.
I’m glad.

Settle in. I’1l tell Ms. Vendegast we made it. Rehearsal isn’t for forty minutes. Listen for the bell. (off Susie’s nod) Knock on the wall if you need anything, okay? I’m right on the other side.  22.
Sara-— Sara turns back.
(re: the room) Is this--?

No. Olga took Patricia's room. It’s the biggest. She said she needed the space. (sotto) She’s Russian. With that, Sara goes. Susie looks around the room, excite It’s simple: A bed, a dresser, a desk, an old-fashioned s with a basin and mirror. But no windows. It’s an interior room inside the center of the building. She has an odd moment of settling into the space, of hear her own breathing. She pulls a suitcase up onto the bed a flips open the latches to start unpacking.
A hand pulls a thick cord and then:
The BELL for rehearsal rings in the residents’ corridor. INT. MARKOS COMPANY, “IRIS” STUDIO -- DAY All the dancers are there, stretching. Madame Blanc and M Tanner come in.
Good morning. Good morning. Tanner goes to join Danielle at the drums for a moment. B goes right in among the dancers.
We have some happier company bus- iness today. I’d like to introduce our new dancer, Susie Bannion. She has come to us from America and I know you’1ll all make her very wel- come. (beat) (MORE )
I saw her audition myself. I can as- sure you, we’re lucky to have her. Everyone smiles and nods to Susie, some come over to hug or squeeze her shoulder. Olga watches this, irritated by
Would you like to say anything, Su- sie? Susie looks around the group, unprepared.
Oh-- Um. I don’t know! Hello--? (laughing) I’m sorry. I don’t know what to say! Everyone laughs warmly.
I'll talk for now, then: Welcome to our little family. Join in as you feel ready, but there’s no rush. Susie smiles, blushing now. She nods in thanks.

All right. For rehearsal today, we should get right back to where we were last week, with Volk. (beat) I’ve talked to Olga and she will now be dancing the protagonist.
